title: 111_s186
content: The Act may be cited as the "South Park National Heritage Area Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The Act, known as the "South Park National Heritage Area Act," defines key terms such as Board, Heritage Area, Management entity, Management plan, and Map. The "South Park National Heritage Area Act" defines terms like partner, Secretary, State, and technical assistance. The "South Park National Heritage Area Act" establishes the South Park National Heritage Area. The South Park National Heritage Area is established in the State with defined boundaries as shown on the map. The management entity for the Heritage Area is the Park County Tourism & Community Development Office, working with the South Park National Heritage Area Board of Directors consisting of representatives from various entities involved in the planning and development of the area. The South Park National Heritage Area is managed by the Park County Tourism & Community Development Office, in collaboration with the Board of Directors made up of representatives involved in the planning and development of the area before the enactment of this Act. The South Park National Heritage Area is managed by the Park County Tourism & Community Development Office, in collaboration with the Board of Directors. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION. The management entity in the South Park National Heritage Area is prohibited from using Federal funds to acquire real property. The Secretary can use funds to make grants, enter into agreements, provide technical assistance, and hire staff with expertise in resource protection and heritage planning. The management entity in the South Park National Heritage Area is responsible for resources protection, fundraising, heritage facility planning, and development, as well as heritage tourism programming. They can obtain funds or services from any source, enter into contracts, and facilitate projects that further the Heritage Area. Their duties include preparing and submitting a management plan to the Secretary, assisting local entities in carrying out the plan, and implementing programs and projects. The management entity in the South Park National Heritage Area is responsible for carrying out programs and projects to recognize, protect, enhance, and promote resource values, establishing interpretive exhibits, developing economic opportunities, increasing public awareness, protecting historic sites, and ensuring clear signage for public access. The management entity in the South Park National Heritage Area is responsible for promoting partnerships, planning new attractions, and considering diverse interests in the management plan. Public meetings are held semiannually for development updates. Federal funds received must be accounted for annually. The management entity in the South Park National Heritage Area must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing activities, expenses, and income. They must also provide all records for audit and ensure organizations receiving funds do the same. Additionally, they are required to promote economic viability. The management entity in the South Park National Heritage Area must promote economic viability. The Federal share of the cost for any activity under this Act is 50 percent. The management entity in the South Park National Heritage Area must promote economic viability with a Federal cost share of 50 percent. The management entity in the South Park National Heritage Area must submit a proposed management plan to the Secretary within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should integrate various approaches for the protection and promotion of resources, consider State and local plans, and include an inventory of resources within the designated areas. The proposed management plan for the South Park National Heritage Area should include policies, strategies, and recommendations for conservation, funding, management, development, and promotion. It should also outline actions by governments, private organizations, and individuals to protect the historical, cultural, scenic, recreational, agricultural, and natural resources of the Heritage Area. The management plan for the South Park National Heritage Area should include actions for ongoing collaboration among partners, specific commitments for the first 5 years, and identification of funding sources. The management plan for the South Park National Heritage Area should include recommendations for coordinating Federal, State, and local programs, an interpretive plan, and policies for resource management. The deadline for submitting the proposed management plan is 3 years after the date of enactment. The management entity must submit a management plan to the Secretary within 3 years of the Act's enactment. If the plan is not approved within 180 days, the entity will be ineligible for additional funding until approval is received. The plan should represent diverse interests in the Heritage Area. The management entity must submit a management plan to the Secretary within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should involve various stakeholders and provide opportunities for public and governmental involvement. Strategies in the plan should aim to balance the protection and development of natural, historical, cultural, scenic, recreational, and agricultural resources in the Heritage Area. If the plan is disapproved, the Secretary will take necessary actions. The Secretary must advise the management entity in writing of reasons for disapproval, make recommendations for revisions, and approve or disapprove proposed revisions within 180 days. The Secretary will also approve or disapprove any substantial amendments to the management plan. The management entity cannot use Federal funds for amendments without approval. The management entity must obtain approval from the Secretary before using Federal funds for any amendments to the management plan. SEC. 6. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES. In General, this Act does not affect a Federal agency's authority to provide assistance under other laws. Federal agencies planning activities impacting the Heritage Area should consult with the Secretary and management entity. This Act does not modify laws authorizing Federal land management or limit a land manager's discretion within the Heritage Area boundaries. SEC. 7. PRIVATE PROPERTY AND REGULATORY PROTECTIONS. The Act does not limit property owners' rights, including the right to not participate in Heritage Area activities, require public access to private property, change existing land use regulations, or claim water rights. The Heritage Area Act does not limit property owners' rights, including the right to not participate in activities, require public access to private property, change land use regulations, or claim water rights. It also prohibits any actions that diminish the State's authority to manage fish and wildlife or create liability for private property owners regarding injuries on their property. SEC. 8. EVALUATION; REPORT. The Secretary must conduct an evaluation of the Heritage Area's accomplishments and prepare a report before Federal funding ends. The evaluation will assess the management entity's progress in achieving the purposes and goals of the management plan, analyze investments, and review the management structure and partnerships. The Secretary will review the management structure, partnership relationships, and funding of the Heritage Area to identify critical components for sustainability. A report will be prepared with recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service, including an analysis of ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding if reauthorization is recommended. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress, including recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service and ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding. Authorization of appropriations for this Act is set at $10,000,000, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The Secretary's authority to provide assistance under this Act will end 15 years after its enactment.
